title-group.article-title: Additively Manufactured Flexible Electronics Filled with Ionic Liquid for Cryogenic Pressure Sensing

article-meta.aff: 1Sauvage Laboratory for Smart Materials, Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Flexible Printed Electronics Technology, Harbin Institute of Technology (Shenzhen), Shenzhen, China.
2State Key Laboratory of Advanced Welding and Joining (Shenzhen), Harbin Institute of Technology (Shenzhen), Shenzhen, China.

fn.p: These authors contributed equally to this paper.

license.license-p: Exclusive licensee Beijing Institute of Aerospace Control Devices. No claim to original U.S. Government Works. Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution License 4.0 (CC BY 4.0).

abstract.p: Flexible electronics have attracted increasing attention and are extensively used in medical care and health monitoring applications. However, research on their applications in low-temperature environments is limited, mainly owing to material intrinsic limitation. In this work, a cryogenic pressure sensor using low-melting (−71 °C) ionic liquid 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([BMIM]BF4) is fabricated via the template removal method. The sensor unit can function at temperatures ranging from −50 to 30 °C, with improved sensing performance at lower temperatures. At −50 °C, it demonstrates an ultralow detection limit of 0.5 Pa and a high sensitivity of 2.0 × 105 Ω/kPa, thereby enabling the detection of dynamic pressure loads with different frequencies (0.2 to 2 Hz) and waveforms (sine and triangle). Subsequently, these units are integrated into a 3 × 3 array and embedded into a bionic thumb. The sensor can accurately identify up to 9 independent touch points and recognize dynamic sliding with velocities in the range of 0.31 to 4.42 cm/s at an extremely low temperature (−50 °C), thus demonstrating remarkable multitouch and sliding trajectory recognition capabilities. Furthermore, the proposed sensor unit is expected to contribute to the research on the human–machine interface of space suits.

institution-wrap.institution: Shenzhen Science and Technology Planning Project

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, electronic skin has attracted extensive research interest owing to its efficient emulation of human skin characteristics such as static and dynamic pressure sensing and high stretchability [1–10]. As electronic skin is a multifunctional sensor, it should satisfy the requirements of good sensitivity, high detection limits, low response time, high stretchability, and high mechanical strength [3–11] in addition to covering irregular surfaces [9–12]. Thus far, materials such as liquid metal and conductive hydrogel have been used as the conductive medium of flexible electronics, exhibiting excellent sensitivity and response time [13–18]. Liquid metal is used in various fields because of its good conductivity, high thermal conductivity, excellent mechanical properties, and low viscosity [19–21]. The metal-liquid-based flexible electronics are essential components of the functional human–machine interface and E skin [22–24]. Hydrogels, characterized by their unique 3-dimensional polymer networks containing water molecules structures, have emerged as highly prospective candidates for flexible electronics [25–28]. Several soft electronics, such as actuators and touchpads containing hydrogels, exhibit excellent performance [29–31]. Another common conductive material is 2-dimensional (2D) materials. 2D materials have demonstrated important potential in flexible electronics due to their unique electrical and mechanical properties [32]. Research on 2D-material sensing devices has emerged in recent years, showing promising applications in various areas such as healthcare and intelligent screens [33–35]. However, as the melting point of common liquid metal is approximately 10 to 30 °C [36], it may freeze at low temperatures; hydrogels are also prone to freezing in a cryogenic environment. Therefore, sensors based on these materials are difficult to apply in harsh environments. Meanwhile, research on 2D-material sensors for use in low-temperature environments is nearly blank. Recently, ionic liquids have become a new conducting medium for electronic skin [37–39]. Ionic liquids are composed entirely of positively and negatively charged ions [40]. Their properties include nonvolatility, low vapor pressure, noninflammability, wide electrochemical windows, high thermal stability, and excellent conductivity [37–41]. Ionic liquids are also referred to as “designer solvents” as their thermophysical properties can be tailored by adjusting the composition of the ions to fit practical needs [41]. By selecting appropriate cation-anion combinations, ionic liquids with melting points as low as −87 °C can be obtained [42], thus ensuring their retention in a liquid state even at extremely low temperatures and maintaining outstanding conductivity performance.

At present, research on ionic liquid as a conductive medium is still limited. Jiang et al. [43] encapsulated ionic liquid in the tailored cavity with a stretchable polydimethylsiloxane thin film to design stretchable and transparent multifunctional sensors. The designed ionic-liquid-based sensor exhibits high sensitivity and good linearity for strain and temperature, accurately detecting the density of these stimuli in real-time. However, this sensor performs poorly under low temperatures and is unable to detect sliding pressure.

This study employs a low-melting-point (−87 °C) ionic liquid, 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([BMIM]BF4), as the sensing medium to successfully fabricate a cryogenic pressure sensor capable of operating at low temperatures. Our flexible electronics can maintain extraordinary performance under low environments (−50 °C) as they have the lowest sensing temperature among the sensors of the same type. The functionality of the fabricated sensing element is demonstrated within the temperature range of −50 to 30 °C, with an enhanced sensing performance with decreasing temperature. At −50 °C, it exhibits ultrasensitive detection limits (0.5 Pa) and remarkably high sensitivity (2.0 × 105 Ω/kPa), allowing for dynamic pressure load detection of different waveforms (sinusoidal and triangular) at frequencies ranging from 0.2 to 2 Hz. Subsequently, the sensing elements are integrated into a 3 × 3 array and embedded in a biomimetic thumb to simulate the sensor performance of a thumb under extremely low temperatures. The biomimetic thumb accurately identifies the load at 9 different positions and recognizes the sliding trajectories and velocities between these positions at low temperatures (−50 °C), demonstrating excellent multitouch sensing and sliding trajectory recognition capabilities.

sec.title: Template preparation
sec.p: This study uses stereolithography technology to manufacture removable templates for preparing flexible pressure sensors. A 3-dimensional (3D) printer (BMF S130) is used to print templates of different cross-sectional sizes (80 μm × 80 μm, 100 μm × 100 μm, 120 μm × 120 μm, 150 μm × 150 μm, and 200 μm × 200 μm, with 1 turn) and different numbers of turns (1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 turns, with a cross-sectional size of 80 μm × 80 μm). The length of the template is 28 mm. Ecoflex 00-30 flexible silicone gel components A and B are uniformly mixed in a ratio of 1:1 and coated on the template. The template is placed on a horizontal table and then cured at 30 °C for 30 min to prepare for the upper passivation layer. A 3D printer (X400) is used to print a lower passivation layer template with a size of 80 mm × 40 mm. Polydimethylsiloxane is mixed with the curing agent in a ratio of 10:1, coated on the template, and dried at 45 °C for 3 h. Then, the upper passivation layer is placed on the lower passivation layer to completely fit, after which it is dried at 45 °C for 6 h.

sec.title: Sensor unit preparation
sec.p: A medical syringe is used to inject 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([BMIM]BF4) ionic liquid from the microchannel outlet into the mold. Copper wires are drawn out from both ends of the microchannel, wrapped with epoxy resin AB glue, and dried at 30 °C for 5 h.

sec.title: Performance testing
sec.p: To test the pressure characteristics of the sensor unit, 10 weights (50, 20, 10, 5, 2, 1, 0.5, 0.2, 0.1, and 0.05 g) are used to apply pressure separately, and a multimeter (Keithley DMM7510) is used to test the unit resistance. Experimental environments of different temperatures (−50, −30, −10, 10, and 30 °C) are set using a low-temperature freezer.

sec.title: Low-frequency deformation detection
sec.p: A waveform generator, oscillator, and signal generator are used to output and amplify low-frequency signals with frequencies of 0.2, 0.5, 0.8, 1, and 2 Hz, and corresponding deformations are generated at a low temperature (−50 °C). The waveforms used include sine waves and triangle waves, and the amplitude of the simulated signal is 1 Vpp. The resistance is tested using a multimeter (Keithley DMM7510).

sec.title: Array static pressure test
sec.p: Nine different weights (0.5, 1, 5, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 g) are used to apply pressure at a low temperature (−50 °C). The resistance is tested using a multimeter (Keithley DMM7510).

sec.title: Sliding test
sec.p: A 10-g weight is used to perform single-point sliding tests in “□” and “Z” shapes. Three copper rods are used to perform “1” type ballistic sliding tests. The experimental temperature is −50 °C.

sec.title: Bionic thumb test
sec.p: A 3D printer (Hori X400) is used to print a thumb model. Static pressure and perform dynamic sliding are applied to the model with a copper rod to complete the performance test at −50 °C.

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: The sensor unit is fabricated using the template removal method. As shown in Fig. 1A, the upper-layer template is printed using a BMF S130 printer, and the blank template is printed using an X400 3D printer. The 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([BMIM]BF4) ionic liquid is injected into the shell from the microchannel outlet using a medical syringe. Mechanical properties are tested in Fig. S1. The results show that the sensor exhibits excellent stability, thereby satisfying the practical requirements.

caption.p: Ionic liquid flexible sensor. (A) Schematic of the sensor fabrication process. (B to D) Schematic of the sensing test. (E) Schematic of the bionic thumb model.

sec.p: The flexible sensor can accurately identify static and dynamic pressure at low temperatures, exhibiting excellent performance (Fig. 1B to D). Moreover, the touch performance of the sensor embedded in the bionic thumb is comparable to human skin (Fig. 1E).

To determine the optimal parameters, the resistance drift of the sensor unit is first investigated. Resistance drift refers to the unwanted resistance changes that occur independent of the input quantity in response to external environmental interference; this can significantly affect the sensor’s performance. In this work, the resistance drift can be controlled by adjusting the cross-sectional area of the microchannel (Fig. 2A and B). The minimum print limit of the Mankati S130 printer is 10 μm; however, when the channel’s height is less than 80 μm, the upper and lower surfaces of the channel may adhere to each other, resulting in channel blockage. Therefore, the minimum print size of the channel is set to 80 μm × 80 μm. As the microchannel is compressed, the resistance drift rate and critical drift time of the sensor decrease. This can be attributed to the fact that under external load pressure, a smaller cross-sectional area leads to a higher shear stress in the ionic liquid and reduces the diffusion distance, thereby reducing its resistance drift rate and critical drift time. When the cross-sectional area of the channel reaches the minimum, the impact of resistance drift can be neglected, ensuring the accuracy of the sensor.

caption.p: Electrical performance. (A) Resistance drift rate with different channel section sizes. (B) Fitting curves of critical drift time of resistance of sensor parts with different section sizes. (C) Resistance changes of accumulated weights with different channel section sizes. (D) Resistance changes of accumulated weights with different upper passivation layer thicknesses. (E) Resistance changes of accumulated weights with varying complexity. (F) Fitting curve of resistance variation with varying complexity. (G) Schematics of different curvature models. (H) Resistance changes of accumulated weights under different curved surfaces. (I) Fitting curve of resistance variation with applied pressure under curved surface conditions.

sec.p: Subsequently, experiments are performed to analyze the impact of varying design parameters on the sensitivity. Sensitivity is considered as a critical parameter for the sensor, which is influenced by several factors. First, the influence of the microchannel cross-sectional size is examined, and the results are shown in Fig. 2C. Under the same external load pressure, the detection sensitivity increases as the microchannel cross-sectional size decreases. This can be attributed to the deformation of the channels caused by the squeeze of Ecoflex flexible substrate. A smaller cross-sectional area leads to a lower relative deformation, resulting in a smaller change in resistance.

Subsequently, the impact of the upper passivation layer thickness is examined (Fig. 2D). The resistance under the same pressure increases with increasing thickness, reaching its maximum at a thickness of 2.5 mm and decreasing thereafter. However, further analysis of the second half of the curve indicates that a 2.5-mm-thick unit only has a detection limit of 50 Pa, whereas a 1.0-mm-thick unit can reach 0.5 Pa. Therefore, the sensing unit with a passivation layer thickness of 1.0 mm gives the best performance.

Finally, the impact of different circuit complexities are explored (Fig. 2E and F). As the circuit becomes more complex, the resistance change under the same pressure rises, and the slope of the linear fit curve increases from 5.51 × 10−1 to 7.54 × 10−1, thus indicating improved sensitivity.

Based on the test results, the optimal sensing unit adopts a cross-sectional size of 80 μm × 80 μm, a 1.00-mm passivation layer thickness, and a design with 5 channels. The detection limit at 30 °C is 0.5 Pa, with a detection range of 98 to 9,800 Pa, and a detection sensitivity of up to 2.0 × 105 Ω/kPa.

The sensor designed for use in electronic skin should fit irregular curved surfaces. To evaluate the performance of the proposed sensor under such conditions, 4 curved surface models with different bending radii ranging from ∞ to 6 mm are fabricated (Fig. 2G). The sensitivity test results are shown in Fig. 2H and I. The resistance response curve indicates consistent behavior, and the fitting curve exhibits a linear relationship. Therefore, the sensing performance of the ion liquid sensor fabricated in this study can maintain its functionality under different curved surface environments, thus satisfying the requirements for practical application.

Before the integration, experiments are conducted to assess the units’ performance at varying temperatures to ensure the proposed sensor’s functionality in low-temperature environments. First, the impact of temperature on sensitivity is evaluated. As depicted in Fig. 3A and B, the sensing unit exhibits a performance at par with that of human skin at a near-room temperature of 30 °C. As the temperature decreases to −50 °C, the resistance change gradually increases, and the slope of the fitting curve increases from 0.754 to 1.024, indicating a higher sensitivity at low temperatures. The resistance response time at different temperatures is presented in Fig. 3C and D. The sensor’s response time to a 1-g weight is 0.125 s at 30 °C; however, it gradually increases with decreasing temperature. However, it still meets the requirements in low-temperature environments.

caption.p: Influence of temperature on sensing performance and low frequency deformation. (A) Resistance variation at different temperatures. (B) Fitting curve of resistance variation at different temperatures. (C) Resistance response time at different temperatures. (D) Resistance response time at 30 °C with a load of 1 g of weight. (E) Sine wave signals detected at different temperatures.

sec.p: Further, the relationship between temperature and the low-frequency response is investigated to ensure its performance in real-time detection and diagnosis of physiological signals of livings in harsh environments (Fig. 3E). The results show that the sensing unit can accurately detect the applied sinusoidal vibration signal with almost no distortion under various temperatures and that its resistance change increases at lower temperatures. This indicates that the sensing unit can effectively detect deformation of vibration signals of different frequencies in varying environments; thereby exhibiting superior detection performance at low temperatures. As described in Fig. S2, tests are conducted on dynamic pressure loads of triangular waveforms with the same frequency, successfully differentiating between different waveform loads.

Subsequently, the optimal units are integrated into a 3 × 3 array. The pressure sensor comprising 9 sensing units demonstrates remarkable detection ability for static multitouch at low temperatures (Fig. 4A to F). Three-point touch, 5-point touch, and 9-point touch are simulated using 9 different weights at an environmental temperature of −50 °C. The sensing units can respond accurately to touch, and a relatively strong linear relationship (y = 0.06x) exists between the resistance increment and the loading weight, enabling the direct conversion of resistance increment into weight load on the unit. Therefore, the unit has great perception ability for static multitouch.

caption.p: Static and dynamic sensing test. (A) Three-point touch. (B) Five-point touch. (C) Nine-point touch. (D to F) Resistance response test results. (G) Schematic of single-point rolling test. (H) Resistance response results during rolling. (I) Relationship between load and rolling speed.

sec.p: Furthermore, the sensor exhibits proficient detection capabilities during dynamic sliding. The results of the sliding velocity are shown in Fig. 4G and H. The prepared sensing unit is around 4 mm × 4 mm, and the spacing between adjacent units is d = 1.4 mm; therefore, the distance between the center points of adjacent units is d = 5.4 mm. Under an environment of −50 °C, a metal ball weighing 19.20 g is used to roll along the first row of 3 sensing units. When the sliding load is applied, a peak appears and is recorded. The average time interval between adjacent peaks is calculated as t1=tR1+tR22s, and the velocity is calculated as v1=dt1=5.4×2tR1+tR2 cm/s. Similarly, t2=tR2+tR32s, and v2=dt2=5.4×2tR2+tR3 cm/s. Thus, the average velocity is obtained as v=v1+v22 cm/s. The proposed sensor can effectively detect a rolling speed of 0.31 to 4.4 cm/s, and the average resistance value corresponding to different rolling speeds can be obtained; therefore, the equivalent load during rolling can be determined.

Meanwhile, the calculation reveals that the accuracy of pattern recognition is closely tied to the response time. A smaller response time ensures that the resistance reaches its peak before the ball moves through, thereby enhancing accuracy. In our work, we demonstrate that response time decreases when the temperature gets higher. Therefore, speed recognition ranging from 0.31 to 4.42 cm/s at −50 °C is only the lowest detection range. Our device is able to recognize wider speed range when temperature rises.

Subsequently, sliding trajectory experiments are conducted at −50 °C. A weight of 10 g is used to slide along “□” and “Z” shapes on the surface. The response results show that each sensing unit can respond in sequence and successfully present the preset trajectory. Moreover, the applied pressure can be evaluated using the reference value. In addition, 3 identical iron rods are used for 3-point sliding detection. The sensing units 4, 5, and 6 are subjected to pressure of approximately 26 kPa during sliding, and the pressure on both sides is relatively small. The sensor array accurately responds to multipoint sliding and has good response capability for both static touch and dynamic sliding at low temperatures. Therefore, it can provide precise pressure sensing in low-temperature environments. The detailed results of the experiments are presented in Fig. 5A to C.

caption.p: Sliding tests. (A) “□” - Sliding results. (B) “Z” – Sliding results. (C) Three-point sliding results.

sec.p: Further, a bionic thumb model is fabricated with an embedded 3 × 3 array of sensing units on its surface based on Ecoflex. The 3-point touch and dynamic sliding experiments are conducted at −50 °C, and the results are presented in Fig. 6A to L and Tables 1 and 2. In the static touch test, the maximum pressure is observed on sensing unit No.4 at approximately 19.30 kPa, and the minimum pressure is observed on sensing unit No.9 at approximately 17.40 kPa. In the sliding experiment, the sensing array displays clear and accurate detection of the preset “1”, “2”, “3”, “H”, “I”, and “T” sliding trajectories, providing information on the applied pressure. Thus, the proposed cryogenic sensor can respond to the position and pressure of both static touch and dynamic sliding on curved surfaces in low-temperature environments; furthermore, it outperforms other sensors of the same type (Fig. 6M). These results highlight the potential of the proposed sensor for diverse applications and provide new ideas for the application of electronic skin in low-temperature environments.

caption.p: Response of the bionic thumb model and performance comparison. (A to D) Three-point static touch. (E to H) “1”, “2” “3” - track slide test. (I to L) “H”, “I”, “T” - track slide test. (M) Performance comparison [1,5–7,38].
Multitouch detection of the bionic thumb model (kPa)
Bionic thumb model sliding trajectory detection (kPa)

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study fabricated a cryogenic electronic skin based on ionic liquid using the template removal method. The skin can operate over a wide temperature range (−50 to 30 °C) with a low detection limit (0.5 Pa) and high sensitivity (2.0 × 105 Ω/kPa), enabling the detection of deformations at different frequencies (0.2 to 2 Hz) at various temperatures. The skin exhibits excellent performance in multipoint touch sensing and dynamic slide recognition, can accurately identify the location and magnitude of loaded pressure, and can sense dynamic sliding speeds ranging from 0.31 to 4.42 cm/s. This study provides a new approach for manufacturing cryogenic flexible electronics for sensing under low-temperature environments, thus broadening the application of flexible electronic sensors in low and low-temperature environments, such as the human–machine interface of space suits.

sec.title: Data Availability
sec.p: The authors declare that the primary data supporting the findings of this study are available within the paper and its supplementary information files. Additional data are available from the corresponding authors upon reasonable request.
